title: Examples
section: Control when language names are visible
text:
Control when language names are visible

Document-wide
By default, the language name will be added to all language-specific blocks in the document. You can disable this with the show-all option in the YAML front matter:


---
title: Your title
filters:
  - language-name
language-name:
  show-all: false
---



In specific blocks
You can also enable or disable language names on a block-by-block basis with the show-language attribute, which can be either true or false. For instance:

SourceOutput


```{.r show-language="false"}
# No language name
x <- 1 + 1
```


# No language name
x <- 1 + 1




SourceOutput


```{.r show-language="true"}
# Language name!
x <- 1 + 1
```




# Language name!
x <- 1 + 1

title: Examples
text:
Control language name
By default, the language will be converted to sentence case (i.e. first letter capitalized). This works for many languages, like R and Python. For example, this Python chunk renders with a title of “Python”:

SourceOutput


```{.python}
x = 1 + 1
```




x = 1 + 1




For languages like YAML, though, the name will render as “Yaml”:


items:
  - thing 1
  - thing 2

You can control the text for the language name with the language-title option:

SourceOutput


```{.yaml language-title="YAML"}
items:
  - thing 1
  - thing 2
```




items:
  - thing 1
  - thing 2




You can use whatever you want in the language-title option, like adding extra language details:

OutputSource




x = 1 + 1



print x



print(x)



```{.python language-title="Python (both 2 and 3)"}
x = 1 + 1
```

```{.python language-title="Python 2"}
print x
```

```{.python language-title="Python 3"}
print(x)
```



Here are some other examples:

OutputSource




quarto preview document.qmd --no-browser



```{.bash language-title="Terminal (sh)"}
quarto preview document.qmd --no-browser
```




OutputSource




reg y x, robust



```{.stata language-title="Stata ($$$)"}
reg y x, robust
```

title: Examples
text:
Computational output
This also works with computational cells:



mean(1:5)


[1] 3


You can control options within computational cells as well using inline attributes. Here’s a custom language name:

OutputSource





mean(1:5)


[1] 3




```{r}
#| language-title: "R (the best)"

mean(1:5)
```



And here’s a chunk with no language name:

OutputSource



mean(1:5)

[1] 3




```{r}
#| show-language: false

mean(1:5)
```



It also works when using the filename attribute:

OutputSource







analysis.R

mean(1:5)



[1] 3




```{r}
#| language-title: "R (the best)"
#| filename: "analysis.R"

mean(1:5)
```

title: Quarto language name
text:
In multilingual (programming languages; not human languages) Quarto documents, there’s no easy way to indicate what language code is in. You can describe it with text and comments:
Here’s some R code:
# This is R!
# (some people like the = instead of the <-)
x = 1 + 1
And here’s some Python code:
# This is Python!
x = 1 + 1
But the reader has to read the preceding text and check the comments. With things like Observable JS, it’s easy to have a document (like this) that works with R or Python, makes an R or Python object available to Observable, and then plots it with Observable Plot. Within the document, however, all the languages will look the same—they’ll be syntax-highlighted correctly according to each language, but there won’t be a clear signal of what each code chunk is.
The Tabby Quarto extension makes it easy to place multilingual chunks of code side-by-side as panels in a tabset, but that’s mostly for showing the same code across multiple languages and won’t work well in a document that mixes languages throughout.
This extension uses CSS pseudo-classes to add the name of the language to HTML code blocks:

title: Quarto language name
text:
Installation
To install this extension in your current directory (or into the Quarto project that you’re currently working in), use the following command:
quarto add andrewheiss/language-name
This will install the extension in the _extensions subdirectory. If you’re using version control, you will want to check in this directory.

title: Quarto language name
text:
Usage
Enable the filter by including it in the YAML front matter of a document:
---
title: Your title
filters:
  - language-name
---
By default, the language name will be added to all language-specific blocks in the document. You can disable this with the show-all option in the YAML front matter:
---
title: Your title
filters:
  - language-name
language-name:
  show-all: false
---
You can control whether a name appears within each block of code with the show-language option:
```{.r show-language="false"}
# No language name
x <- 1 + 1
```
```{.r show-language="true"}
# Yes language name
x <- 1 + 1
```
You can control the text that appears in with the language-title option:
```{.sh language-title="Terminal (sh)"}
$ ls
```
It works with computational chunks too, but the options have to be defined in the chunk options:

```{r}
#| show-language: true
#| language-title: "R (the best)"

mean(1:5)
```

[1] 3

TODO some day!

Make it easier to configure the custom CSS for the language labels.
Right now this only works with HTML output. It would be neat if it worked in other formats (PDF, Typst, Word lol) like Quarto’s native code filename option or the icons in callout blocks.
Right now you have to set a custom title for each chunk that uses it. If your whole document only uses R and Observable, you have to add language-title="Observable JS" to each chunk yourself. It would be cool to have more global custom title settings that you could change up in the document YAML.
